messages: 5b67d980ae4c3c82251106e26913ce67 (15:23): <blockquote><p>[Quoted]</p><p><cite>[Cited]</cite></p></blockquote> isn't the way HTML5 want it, right?
5b67d980ae4c3c82251106e26913ce67 (15:24): What's the reason for that?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:42): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: I'm not sure I understand your round-tripping question
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:42): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: did you mean parse as HTML5, serialize as XHTML5 without namaspace prefix or CDATA sections and reparse as HTML5?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:43): I think there'd be some edge cases related to <pre> or <textarea> content starting with a line feed
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:44): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: as for whether the adoption agency stuff is stable under reparse, I'm not sure

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:49): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 - OK. I was thinking of the use case where somebody might want to take an html source file, parse and serialize to xml because they want to run some xml tool on it (to do some minor xslt transformation on), then serialize that (slightly different) result back to html
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:50): xslt part being just an example
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:50): general case being just to be able to run it through xml tools
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:50): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: that's possible but the HTML serialization may not parse back as the same DOM
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:51): right, Ok
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:51): depends on what kind of tree comes out of the XML tool
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:51): conceptually, that's what the XLST4HTML5 sample program that comes with the V.nu parser does
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:52): yeah, this is coming back to me now from the previous time(s) I asked the same question
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:52): it just skips the parts of serializing to XML and parsing the XML back
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:54): Hixie: test 4 is wrong
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:55): expect(i.nextNode(), document.getElementById('instructions').firstChild);
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:55): expect(i.nextNode(), document.links[0]);
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (15:55): there's a <span></span> in there which you have forgotten in the script, it seems

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (16:00): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 - anyway, the reason I was thinking of it was also because of Norm's blog entry about HTML5 and his mention that 'One of the two ‚Äúauthoring formats‚Äù described by the HTML 5 specification is a custom one.' and 'The goal of the custom parser, as I understand it, is that it imposes an unambiguous HTML 5 interpretation on any random stream of characters."

73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (16:04): Hixie: also, other tests seem to create and insert links, so document.links[0] doesn't point to the link to reference.html. i'm not sure if this is a bug in the test or not, yet
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (16:04): (i.e. when checking against document.links[0] in test 4)
